data.title: Automatically create input node when creating a ShaderGraph
data.body: Closes #1423.

data.title: RichTextEditor size not adjusted by (HBox/VBox/Grid)Container
data.body:
Windows 10 64bit, Godot 2.0.1-stable

RichTextEditor sets size to 0 in HBoxContainer, VBoxContainer and GridContainer. The control size is not properly adjusted to the container.

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create new scene
2. Insert a main node (Node2D or Control)
3. Insert a HBoxContainer, a VBoxContainer, a GridContainer and a RichTextEditor
4. Insert a RichTextEditor to every container (3, there should be 4 RichTextEditors)
5. Enable BBCode in each RichTextEditor, enter some content
6. Optional, add a control to every container as a space filler (buttons, labels, whatever)
7. Start the scene

**Result**
RichTextEditors in the containers are not visible (the one outside works just fine). Additionaly, if you try to resize them in the editor:
VBoxContainer RTE snaps the size to 0 if the height exceeds one line,
HBoxContainer RTE can be resized, but the size is ignored,
GridContainer RTE same as VBoxContainer

**Updates**
Appearantly Containers use the MinSize value as the size (which is 0,0 by default). Setting MinSize makes the element visible, but it's still not adjusted to the text.

data.title: EditorExportPlugin: Option to avoid exporting files
data.body:
Currently, the method `Variant custom_export(String name, EditorExportPlatform platform)` in EditorExportPlugin allows to change the raw contents and the name of the file being exported. This is the method description:

```
1) If returned value is null, the file is exported
as is.

2) If the returned value is a RawAray, the content of that array becomes the new
file being exported.

3) If the file must also change it's name when
exported, then a [Dictionary] must be returned with
two fields: 'name' with the new filename and 'data'
with a [RawArray] containing the raw contents of the
file.
```

This method should also allow not to export the file, e.g:

```
4) If the file must not be exported, then an empty [Dictionary] must be returned.
```

data.title: error(1,0): Invalid member for expression: .xyzz; In shader code that uses swizzling.
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Arch Linux: 4.4.5-1-ARCH x86_64 GNU/Linux

Graphics card info:

```
00:02.0 VGA compatible controller [0300]: Intel Corporation Haswell-ULT Integrated Graphics Controller [8086:0a16] (rev 09) (prog-if 00 [VGA controller])
    Subsystem: Toshiba America Info Systems Device [1179:fa48]
    Flags: bus master, fast devsel, latency 0, IRQ 44
    Memory at f7800000 (64-bit, non-prefetchable) [size=4M]
    Memory at e0000000 (64-bit, prefetchable) [size=256M]
    I/O ports at f000 [size=64]
    Expansion ROM at <unassigned> [disabled]
    Capabilities: <access denied>
    Kernel driver in use: i915
    Kernel modules: i915
```

**Godot verson:**
Godot_v2.0.1_stable_x11.64

**Issue description:**:
When using the following shader code in Godot that demonstrates 'swizzling'...

``` Python
// Blank line #1
vec3 a = vec3(1,2,3);
vec3 b = a.zyx; // b will contain vec3(3,2,1)
vec2 c = a.xy; // c will contain vec2(1,2)
vec4 d = a.xyzz; // d will contain vec4(1,2,3,3)
```

I was given the following error: `error(1,0): Invalid member for expression: .xyzz`.  Also notice that the error message points to line 1 instead of line 5.

Note: This sample code came from the Godot Docs: http://docs.godotengine.org/en/latest/reference/shading_language.html#swizzling

It appears that the vec4 dot notation doesn't work at all without throwing an error.
At first, I thought it was due to the double 'z' character, but Godot doesn't like `vec4 d = a.xyzw;` either.

It appears that the error message originates from shader_language.cpp at line 1892, but my brief look at the code didn't reveal why vec4s don't work and vec2s and vec3s do.
https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/master/servers/visual/shader_language.cpp#L1892

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Open a new project
2. Add a new textureframe to the scene graph
3. Add a new CanvasItemMaterial to the Materials property of the textureframe
4. Add a new CanvasItemShader to the Shader property of the CanvasItemMaterial
5. Edit the new shader and add the sample code above to the textbox that is shown
6. Wait for the shader to be compiled and the error message to be shown below the text area

data.title: Fix crash when importing sub-scenes
data.body: Closes #4048.

data.title: (editor)filedialog open file and dir MODE_OPEN_ANY
data.body:
closes #4019
old PR #4023

How to use/test?

Select a file and you will see a file selected print
Select a dir and you will see a dir selected print
Try to create and save a new scene.

```
extends Node2D

onready var filedialog = get_node( "FileDialog" )

func _ready():
    filedialog.connect("dir_selected", self,"_on_FileDialog_dir_selected")
    filedialog.connect("file_selected", self,"_on_FileDialog_file_selected")
    filedialog.connect("files_selected", self,"_on_FileDialog_files_selected")

    filedialog.set_mode( filedialog.MODE_OPEN_ANY )
    #filedialog.set_mode( filedialog.MODE_SAVE_FILE )
    #filedialog.set_mode( filedialog.MODE_OPEN_FILES )
    #filedialog.set_mode( filedialog.MODE_OPEN_FILE )
    filedialog.popup()

func _on_FileDialog_dir_selected( dir ):
    print("dir selected: " + dir )


func _on_FileDialog_file_selected( path ):
    print("file selected: " + path )

func _on_FileDialog_files_selected( paths ):
    print("files selected: " + str(paths) )
```

It is always returning 43.142562, which shouldn't be the case. I'm on godot 2.0.1, ubuntu.

data.title: Quad node is not selectable via 3D viewport
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Windows 7 64bit

**Issue description (what happened, and what was expected):**
If you load the attached project you will see that if you try to click on the quad in the 3D view, nothing happens. Alt + RMB also does not list the quad underneath the mouse cursor.

A similar thing happens with MeshInstance:

**Steps to reproduce:**
- add a mesh instance node to the scene and load "plane.msh" (included in the project dir)
- the transform gizmo will be visible
- if you unselect the object by clicking somewhere else, the object is no longer selectable via the 3D view
- if you add another object, try a TestCube node for example, the MeshInstance is now selectable via the 3D view. Despite this, Quads are still not selectable.

These may be unrelated, but I thought I'd mention them both here since they are similar and I suspect they might stem from the same thing.

Here's the project: https://dl.dropboxusercontent.com/u/3292249/quad_select.zip
(still can't attach zip files for some reason?)

data.title: var2bytes() always returns the same value regardless of input
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Ubuntu Linux 15.10 64bit, godot built from ad29ee3

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
var2bytes() always returns a RawArray consisting of [2, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0, 0] regardless of what number it's given as input.

**Steps to reproduce:**
var a = var2bytes(12000)
print(a[0], a[1], a[2], a[3])
stdout: 2000

var a = var2bytes(123500)
print(a[0], a[1], a[2], a[3])
stdout: 2000

data.title: Correct spot light size conversion in Blender exporter.
data.body:
Tiny fix.

The collada falloff angle is the angle from the center of the spot
light projection, whereas Blender's point light size is the angle from
one side to the opposite, meaning it's twice as much.

Before:
![](http://i.imgur.com/UQbi4I6.png)

After:
![](http://i.imgur.com/RHIVqSu.png)

data.title: Project manager loads with the size settings of the previously opened project
data.body:
Windows 7 64 bits, Godot 2.0.1

I quit "to project list", then the Project Manager opens in a tiny window that appears to have the same options as the last opened project.

My game had a tiny resolution and a viewport stretch mode. The project manager opened tiny too, and when resized it zooms without filter while keeping the ratio with black bands. Just as my game :p

Open this project: http://zylannprods.fr/dl/godot/ProjectManagerWrongDisplay.zip
Then "quit to project list", notice the weird window size and stretch behaviour.

data.title: Shortcut for adding a skeleton bone requires "launchMedia" key not found on most keyboards.
data.body:
The keyboard shortcut for adding a bone for animation is "Ctrl+LaunchMedia." This shortcut is not useful for any standard keyboard, and should probably be remapped to a button that every user has.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6827480/13732170/5cb5779e-e952-11e5-82a4-cf1ececb9f45.png)

data.title: Node Type - Dictionary Node
data.body:
I would like to request a special node type. This node type would have a dictionary member, with pairs editable (addable, removable, changeable) in the inspector. This node would have a resource field for a JSON file from which information would be loaded on ready(), and a method save() that takes the current values and saves them to the file. The inspector would also have a few buttons to save and load to the json file, and (potentially) the ability to mark certain pairs as read-only.

The ideal use case is with this as the root node for instanced scenes. This way, custom values can be easily changed in the editor without having to edit child nodes (making things cleaner, simpler, and more straightforward). Also, it would add a built-in way to save and load simple data sets without a developer having to copy-paste from the wiki, mitigating potential bugs and streamlining the development of many kinds of games.

data.title: Live Script Reloading
data.body:
Okay, this is something I'm hoping will be exciting for some people. Scripts can now reload themselves automatically when saved, whether for in-editor tool scripts or ingame via the live edit protocol.

I should explain a little bit about how it works internally why I made certains decision on this experimental implementation. Firstly, regarding tool scripts, the way the editor currently handles non-tool scripts is that when they are instanced, if the script server is turned off which it is when in editor mode, the object using a particular script is simply given a null instance of that script, so that even if it is registered to run as a process prior, it won't do anything. Since in my implementation I want to allow non-tool scripts to change into tool scripts a vice-versa, script still need to keep an internal list of objects its attached to. In this case, I used the seemingly unused 'placeholder' list, giving objects a 'placeholder' reference when they attempt to instance a non-tool script with the scripting-engine disabled. When reloaded, instances and placeholders can convert between each other and vice-versa. The pre-existing 'placeholders' might not be the ideal way of storing this, since this implementation currently does not attempt to save members between placeholders and instances, but this can easily be changed depending on how this system should develop going forward. When reloading between instanced scripts, we simply copy the members array, resize the original if nessecary, and then attempt to copy the variables from the old one to the new one using simple string comparisons.

Next point is how scripts attempt to update themselves, particular in relation to script which inherit from other scripts. Internally, this implementation using a 'dirty script list' which attempts to keep a list of all saved scripts ordered based on inheritance hierarchy, meaning that if a script of which another script inherits from is modified, the inheritor will be added to list only after the initial script has updated. Internally, this is done by scanning the 'inheritors' list in a script object which is a tool-specific internal list of objects inheriting this script, not the scripts themselves. A reference-counted list of inherited scripts would be slightly more efficent here, but I didn't really want to change more than I felt I have to in this early implementation, but this can always be refined further. Ensuring the correct order of script reloads in relation to inheritance should work fairly reliably, but it may need to be tested more extensively just in case there's some rare edge-cases I haven't anticipated. This part of the code is mostly confined to the script editor, and there are also some fixes in regards to the various methods of saving scripts, as well as handling scripts being modified from outside of the editor. It should be worth noting that there isn't a really good interface for 'reloading' preexisting resources, so there's some vaguely hacky workarounds going on which have been noted in comments. There's also a fix in another pull request I just sent concerning fixes to the text editor regarding undo/redo, but I decided to send them seperately since while they do affect this feature, it's still kind of a self-contained fix.

Finally, there's reloading scripts in the game itself. Internally, it uses the same ordered dirty list on the editor side as on the game side. It creates a 'live edit' packet consisting of two arrays, one containing the names of the scripts requiring reload, and the other containing the modified source code for each file. The rest is fairly self-explanatory. It might be slightly inefficient to send the entire source code for each file over the protocol, but it shouldn't be a problem for now considering it only does it for files detected as modified, and at most would only ever be done over an internal wi-fi connection. The reason for doing it like this is of course the afformentioned lack of a good interface for reloading resources, but this method should also ensure that script reloading works when debugging a game on an alternative device like a tablet.

One final thing, this feature currently depends on a setting in the text editor 'dynamic_script_reloading_enabled' which is set to be off by default since this is still a somewhat experimental feature, and of course, 'live edit' has to enabled to use this feature with ingame scripts.

That should cover everything, but please ask if there's anything about this implementation which is unclear. This came out of some experiments to see if the editor could be made more 'WYSIWYG-like', so hopefully this should help with speeding up iteration time in game development.

data.title: GDScript binding for TriangulatorPartition::ConvexPartition_HM
data.body:
It would be nice if there was a binding for "TriangulatorPartition::ConvexPartition_HM".
Right now I am writing some buoyancy physics and it would be nice to have convex polygons instead of only being able to triangulate a polygon.
If this is a needed/wanted feature I could do a pull request myself.

data.title: Undo and Redo Text Editor Fix
data.body: The undo and redo commands on the text editor now affect the internal version appropriately, which is needed in the script editor when determining which files have been modified for saving.

data.title: Vector reflect() issue
convert user input time (Dictionary) to Unix time stamp
data.body:
Basically I need this for a todo app - in order to track days remaining  till a future goal date.

1.To do that the user inputs time, which gets converted to a standard dictionary variable.
2. (missing) That time is then converted to unix timestamp
3. We get current time's unix timestamp and we substract the timestamp from step 2
4. (was recently implemented)The resulting timestamp is then converted back to a human readable time (get_time_from_unix_time())

data.title: PacketPeerUDP.wait() infinite loop
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Linux (posix)

**Issue description**:
PacketPeerUDP.wait() never wakes up. It should when receiving a package.

**Steps to reproduce:**

``` python
var udp = PacketPeerUDP.new()
udp.listen(12345)
udp.wait()
#never reaching here
```

**Mistake** (optional but very welcome):
In /drivers/unix/packet_peer_udp_posix.cpp In line 124 the while loop never finishes because p_wait equals true.
In the winsock implementation, p_wait isn't used at all.
I would expect the thread to block, so use p_wait, without the while loop. waisting cpu with polling
doesn't make sense in a wait-method

data.title: Game freeze when ParallaxLayer.mirroring is negative
data.body:
Windows 7 64 bits, Godot 2.0.1

I created a ParallaxLayer under a ParallaxBackground and set mirroring.y to a negative value.
Then I start the game, and it freezes at the loading screen. It doesn't when I set a positive value, or disable camera.current.

Test project: http://zylannprods.fr/dl/godot/ParallaxFreeze.zip

What I initially tried to achieve is to have the background follow the player vertically, for a shoot-em-up game, hence the negative mirroring (I made a post on QA for this: http://www.godotengine.org/qa/1191/negative-parallaxlayer-mirroring-freezes-the-game)

data.title: Add icon region support for ItemList
data.body: A small feature implemented when i was working on another issue. With this you can draw only a part of the item icon.

data.title: Add stop and delete buttons to sample library (supersedes #3339)
data.body:
Based on the work by @rdcklinux in #3339.
The play button becomes a stop button while playing (and goes back to "play" after the sample has finished playing), a delete button is added in the last column.

I removed the global buttons that thus became irrelevant, so in the end it looks like that:
![spectacle z13273](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4701338/13729223/6b710c7a-e930-11e5-98e9-31de8483991e.png)

Before the PR, the SampleLibrary looks like that:
![spectacle a10895](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4701338/13729109/3e789858-e92d-11e5-9d37-24f68788b2e3.png)

A further improvement would be to find a better place for the "Load Sample" icon, which is now alone on its line.

data.title: Exposed int script variables have a maximum limit of 65535
data.body:
If you export an int variable from script like this:
export(int) var my_var

it can only be set to a maximum of 65,535 via the editor as the editor clamps it to that, despite it being able to hold a much larger number.

data.title: "Edit sample" displays a broken panel
data.body:
**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
In Godot 2.0.1 and master branch, when clicking "Edit sample" in the sample library, it loads the characteristics of the sample in the inspector (which is expected), but also displays a broken panel at the bottom:
![spectacle b30671](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4701338/13728454/ab5e8e64-e919-11e5-9cef-9b8fdc73b9bb.png)

Load a project that has a sample library, edit the sample library and click the "Edit sample" button of any sample.

data.title: Godot crashes when opened in Windows 10, 8 and 7 x64 (OpenGL 2.1 is supported)
data.body:
**Operating system or device**:
- Windows 10, 8.x, 7 x64
- Intel(R) G41 Express Chipset
- Tried Godot v2.0, v2.0.1, v1.1

**Issue description**:
The Godot Engine crashes with no error message on cmd when opened.
![godot_crash](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/14921501/13727441/b3e4476e-e918-11e5-9302-54d562ece867.PNG)

---

But my chipset supports OpenGL 2.1 when queried with OpenGL Extension Viewer.
![opengl_snap](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/14921501/13727445/db20d4d2-e918-11e5-891e-eb047b1b5f24.PNG)

---

[Here's the report of the OpenGL specs.](http://pastebin.com/p14Kx5qc)

---

I have checked on Xubuntu 15.10 Live CD on the same system and Godot worked without any issues. In Xubuntu also, the OpenGL version was 2.1.

data.title: Support other HTTP methods rather than just GET in HTTPRequest
data.body:
**Issue description**
I don't know if it is intended that only the `GET` method to be used in `HTTPRequest`, but it would be great to support `POST`, `PUT`, etc. Currently, the `request` function is:

``` gdscript
request(url, custom_headers, ssl_validate_domain)
```

We could put `method` and `request_data` parameters there with default values `GET` and empty string, respectively:

``` gdscript
request(url, custom_headers, ssl_validate_domain, method, request_data)
```
